nodes.text: A face recognition system based on Principal Component Analysis and the eigenface approach can provide a fast, simple and practical solution for recognizing human faces in constrained environments
Training images are represented as vectors and PCA is used to compute eigenvectors (eigenfaces) from the covariance matrix of the training set to define a low dimensional face space

To make PCA computationally feasible, compute eigenvectors of the M by M matrix L = A^T A, then obtain the eigenfaces of the large covariance matrix using a linear combination relation between eigenvectors of L and the covariance matrix
Project each training and test image (after subtracting the mean face) onto the K retained eigenfaces to obtain weight vectors that represent face features in eigenface space
Classify a test face by computing Euclidean distances between its weight vector and all training weight vectors; the class with minimum distance is chosen and a threshold can determine unknown faces
System implementation details: MATLAB implementation using images converted to vectors (example image size used 200 by 149 pixels) and retaining only largest eigenvalues to form K eigenfaces

PCA dimensionality reduction preserves the M largest eigenvalues and corresponding eigenvectors of the covariance matrix, allowing a small set of eigenfaces to describe faces in a high dimensional image space
Prepare the training set by centering and resizing faces, compute the mean face, subtract it from each image, form matrix A of mean-subtracted vectors, and compute L = A^T A for eigen decomposition
Compute feature weights for training samples by inner product of mean-subtracted images with each retained eigenface to form training weight vectors
Testing process: detect and crop face from test image, compute its weight vector using retained eigenfaces, then measure Euclidean distances to training weights for recognition
Experimental evaluation used an institutional database (ETE-07 series, RUET) including 36 images of 18 persons in various poses and image formats (BMP, PNG, JPEG)
Results reported that the implemented PCA eigenface system successfully recognized human faces and performed well across different face orientations under constrained conditions
Recognition decision uses minimum Euclidean distance between test and training weight vectors as a similarity measure
The method gave very good classification across image formats and pose variations in the tested data but has limitations with variations in image size
Limitation: the eigenface approach is constrained by requirement for near-frontal, aligned faces and shows reduced performance with varying image sizes
Future work proposed: extend system to real-time video, enlarge the database, handle varying image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other face recognition methods
